item.title: Graphics with R
item.description: Grammar of ggplot2() Start example df <- data.frame(x=1:15, y=1:15) ggplot(df, aes(x,y)) + geom_point() + labs( title= "Plot example", subtitle = "Subtitled", x="x-values", y = "y-values" ) + theme(panel.background = element_rect(fill = "white", color= "grey50")) Grammar of graphic: ggplot The ggplot2 package is loaded to access the ggplot() function. The graph is created by stacking together several short phrases, each describing an aspect of the graphic. With ggplot, the data need need not to be reshaped for each type of graphical representation (boxplot, histogram, scatter,…).

item.title: Introduction to Data Vizualisation
item.description: Munzner What can be visualized: data, datasets, and attributes Why people are using vis in terms of actions and targets How to design vis idioms: encode, manipulate, facet, and reduce. The four nested levels of vis design have different threats to validity at each level, and validation approaches should be chosen accordingly The effectiveness of channels that modify the appearance of marks depends on matching the expressiveness of channels with the attributes being encoded Eight rules of thumb.

item.title: Introduction to Data Vizualisation
item.description: Application Designing a visualization The use of visualization is pervasive in the scientific production and communication: explanatory diagrams, graphs describing statistics, new experimental data plotted against theoretical expectations, etc. In each case, the author of the visualization tries to lead readers to a specific point of view, by emphasizing some aspects of the data while toning down other aspects. Results may be informative, decisive or misleading. Can you apply the design principles we talked about in class?

item.title: Introduction to GIS - Geographic Information System
item.description: A FINIR Introduction Visualisation of geographic information is become one of the major tool of the digital information analytic. Numerous softwares manage visualization of geographic information from full-scale GIS applications such as ArcGIS and QGIS to web-based tools like Google maps to any number of programing languages. Using a command-line interface has the benefits of enabling both steps analysis and visualization in customizable, transparent and reproducible manner. The goal of this post is to introduce the basic landscape of working with spatial data in R from the perspective of a non-specialist.

item.title: Introduction to Reproducible Analysis
item.description: Reproducible Analysis Typical data analysis workflow looks like this: collect data put it in a file or spreadsheet or database run some analyses, written in various scripts, perhaps saving some intermediate results along the way or maybe always working on the raw data. create some plots or tables of relevant summaries of the data, and then go and write a report about the results in a text editor or word processor.

item.title: Introduction to Survival Analysis
item.description: A FINIR Exercise - Unemployment duration Survival analysis models covariates that influence time-to-event. OLS regression methods are less efficient because the time-to-event is typically not normally distributed (positive, skewed, nearly discret when rounding are present), and the model cannot handle censored observation, without modification. library(Ecdat) ## Warning: le package 'Ecdat' a été compilé avec la version R 3.6.3 ## Le chargement a nécessité le package : Ecfun ## Warning: le package 'Ecfun' a été compilé avec la version R 3.

item.title: Introduction to Survival Analysis
item.description: A FINIR Introduction corresponds to a set of statistical approaches used to investigate the of interest to occur. Medecine, sociology, economy informatics, engineering,… In basic categorical data analysis for example, we compare proportions (risks, rates, etc) between different groups. Such analysis is performed using a chi-square or fisher exact test, or logistic regression. We implicitly assume that the rates are constant over the period of the study, and are defined by the different groups studied.

item.title: Introductory Cases Studies
item.description: Case Study Work group: By group of 5 to 6 students: you will explore one of the following links you will search for the data type, qualification, etc you will question the workflow supporting the website you will question the interpretation, the vizualisation of the results, its strengths and weaknesses you will present your result using an RMarkdown presentation (HTML IoSlides or Beamer) - No more than 4 slides First: names, title, link as subtitle Second: survey of the data elements Third: workflow 1 Fourth: critical analysis Cases - links CS1 - Coronavirus Data https://coronavirus.
